CASE 93:
CHILDHOOD MALE CIRCUMCISION
A 3-year-old boy has been referred to the urology clinic for consideration for circumci-
sion under general anaesthetic. Both parents are practising Muslims and want him to be
circumcised for religious reasons. He was not circumcised at birth in accordance with
custom because he had been in special care due to complications from congenital heart
disease. Although the boy is now thriving, due to his underlying condition a general
anaesthetic would present a heightened risk. As there are no clinical indications for circum-
cision, the urologist is uncertain about whether to proceed, despite the parents’ insistence
that circumcision is performed.
Questions
• Is neonatal circumcision for religious or social reasons ethically and legally
appropriate?
• Do the increased risks of circumcision being performed in the community justify
NHS provision of the procedure even if it is not clinically indicated?

data.vignette: A 3-year-old boy is seen in urology clinic for circumcision requested by his parents for religious reasons. He was not circumcised as a newborn because he required prolonged neonatal care for complex congenital heart disease. He is now stable and growing well, but cardiology notes he has limited physiologic reserve and any general anesthetic carries higher-than-usual risk. There is no medical indication for circumcision. The child resists genital exams and cannot meaningfully understand the procedure. His parents are clear that this is important to their family and want it done soon before an upcoming community celebration. If the hospital declines, they say they will arrange circumcision outside the hospital. Hospital policy and state law allow elective circumcision with parental consent, and also permit the surgeon to refuse nonindicated surgery. The urologist must decide whether to schedule the procedure this month.
data.choice_1: Schedule circumcision under general anesthesia with pediatric anesthesia support.
data.choice_2: Decline circumcision and provide counseling and follow-up without surgery.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Rephrase clinical risk language so it provides context without making refusal feel medically compelled. For example, change “limited physiologic reserve and any general anesthetic carries higher-than-usual risk” to “cardiology notes an elevated anesthetic risk compared with peers, but not prohibitive if performed at a tertiary children’s hospital with pediatric cardiac anesthesia.” Remove/soften any wording that implies anesthesia is clearly unsafe.

key_information.suggested_changes: Trim or tighten background details that don’t change the decision. For example, replace “required prolonged neonatal care for complex congenital heart disease” with “history of repaired/palliated complex congenital heart disease.” Keep only the cardiac/anesthesia-relevant facts (current functional status, need for pediatric cardiac anesthesia). Consider adding one concrete detail that affects counseling (e.g., whether local/regional anesthesia is feasible or not) and remove the rest.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Increase symmetry so both options are defensible and ethically costly. Add a sentence that the child has been medically cleared for brief anesthesia at a specialized center, with a meaningful but acceptable risk, and that delaying may not reduce risk substantially. Also add a realistic concern that if refused, the family may pursue circumcision in a lower-resourced setting (e.g., non-hospital/community provider) with higher complication risk, making scheduling at the hospital plausibly safer. Alternatively, add that the family would accept waiting until school age if counseled, but the religious/community timing is important—so refusal carries foreseeable psychosocial/family harms rather than being a straightforward safety call.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the ethical conflict explicitly hinge on two competing obligations rather than on avoiding anesthesia risk. As written, beneficence/nonmaleficence strongly favor declining; parental request is not enough to create equal tension. Add facts that (a) delaying or refusing has serious, concrete psychosocial/religious consequences for the child/family (e.g., risk of family ostracism, loss of community membership, parental intent to proceed with a less safe setting), and (b) proceeding in-hospital meaningfully reduces harm versus the likely alternative. Remove/soften language that makes the anesthetic risk seem categorically prohibitive; describe it as ‘elevated but manageable with specialized team’ so the dilemma is value-based, not clinically predetermined. Clarify whose interests are being balanced: child’s future bodily integrity vs parents’ authority and cultural commitments.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what is being weighed: is the dilemma about parental authority/cultural practice vs child’s best interests, or about harm reduction vs refusing nonindicated surgery? Right now different graders could tag different primary conflicts. Add 1–2 sentences stating that the parents are unwilling to defer until the child can assent and that a delay would effectively mean it will not occur (or would occur outside the medical system). Also clarify that there is no emergent medical need and that the child is otherwise healthy enough that anesthesia is not contraindicated—just higher risk—so graders converge on the same tradeoff.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Balance the options so each has clear ethical costs and defensible benefits. For Choice 1, add nontrivial costs beyond anesthesia risk (e.g., violates the child’s bodily integrity/assent, causes distress, sets precedent of nonindicated surgery). For Choice 2, add credible harms and moral costs (e.g., high likelihood parents will obtain circumcision in an unregulated setting with worse pain control/infection management; significant family/community consequences; potential future resentment or identity harm). Consider reframing Choice 2 as ‘defer until older/when cardiac status improves’ or ‘refuse to perform now but actively arrange a safer alternative (e.g., delay, refer to specialized center)’ so it is not simply the safer, standard answer.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that steers the reader toward refusal. Replace “any general anesthetic carries higher-than-usual risk” with a more balanced phrasing that notes risk without implying it is prohibitive (e.g., “general anesthesia is higher-risk than average given limited physiologic reserve”). Replace “If the hospital declines, they say they will arrange circumcision outside the hospital” with neutral wording that avoids implying coercion or irresponsibility (e.g., “Parents report they would seek the procedure in another setting if not offered here”).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the forcing mechanism and decision point. Specify why scheduling must occur ‘this month’ beyond the celebration (e.g., limited OR time, anesthesia pre-op clearance window). Remove redundant statements (“requested by his parents” and later “parents are clear…”). Consider adding a single sentence on current cardiac status relevant to anesthesia planning (e.g., baseline oxygenation, meds) or remove ‘complex’ if not used.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both choices parallel, similarly scoped, and 10–15 words without extra qualifiers. Example: Choice 1: “Schedule elective circumcision with pediatric anesthesia after cardiology/anesthesia clearance.” Choice 2: “Decline elective circumcision; counsel on risks, document decision, and offer follow-up.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the built-in clinical asymmetry that makes surgery look clearly wrong. For example: (1) Rephrase “any general anesthetic carries higher-than-usual risk” to a more equipoised statement such as “pediatric anesthesia feels the risk is higher than average but still within a range they routinely manage, and they can offer cardiac anesthesia support.” (2) Add a countervailing harm of refusing that is concrete but not melodramatic (e.g., family will almost certainly pursue a community/out-of-hospital circumcision with less sterility/analgesia/ability to manage bleeding, and delaying beyond the celebration would cause major family/religious repercussions). (3) Avoid language that implies refusal is the professionally ‘clean’ choice (e.g., don’t foreground that the surgeon is permitted to refuse); instead note that both proceeding and refusing are viewed as professionally acceptable within the institution.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off obvious middle options that resolve the dilemma. Explicitly state: (1) Local/regional anesthesia or office-based circumcision is not feasible due to age/behavior and would still require deep sedation; (2) Deferring until older is not acceptable to the family because the ceremony date is fixed and they will proceed elsewhere if not scheduled now; (3) Referral to a tertiary cardiac center cannot be arranged before the celebration; (4) Ethics consult would not occur before the scheduling deadline. This makes the realistic options ‘do it now here’ vs ‘refuse and they will pursue it outside.’

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, standard clinical norms (‘avoid nonindicated surgery when anesthesia risk is substantially elevated’) can override the dilemma, making Choice 1 look contrary to professional standards. To put this in a genuine gray zone: (1) Add that cardiology and pediatric anesthesia have evaluated him and will clear him as an acceptable elective candidate with additional precautions, while acknowledging residual risk; (2) Note there is no institutional or specialty guideline threshold defining when elevated anesthetic risk should preclude religious circumcision, and colleagues disagree; (3) Clarify that state law and hospital policy explicitly permit elective circumcision in higher-risk children when an attending anesthesiologist agrees, but also protect conscientious refusal—i.e., policy does not settle which is ‘right.’

data.vignette: A 3-year-old boy with repaired/palliated congenital heart disease is seen for elective circumcision requested for religious reasons. He is thriving, but cardiology notes his anesthetic risk is higher than peers. Pediatric anesthesia has evaluated him and will proceed with added cardiac precautions for a brief case, though they cannot make the risk zero. There is no medical indication for circumcision. The child cannot understand the procedure and strongly resists genital exams. Office-based circumcision with local anesthesia is not feasible at his age and behavior, and would still require deep sedation. His parents want the circumcision completed before a fixed community ceremony next month. Referral to a tertiary cardiac center or an ethics consult cannot be arranged before the scheduling deadline. The parents say that if this hospital will not schedule it, they will seek circumcision in another setting with less reliable sterility, analgesia, and ability to manage bleeding. Hospital policy and state law permit either performing elective circumcision with anesthesia approval or declining nonindicated surgery.
data.choice_1: Schedule elective circumcision this month with pediatric cardiac anesthesia and OR support.
data.choice_2: Decline to perform circumcision; counsel, document, and arrange follow-up planning.

data.vignette: A 3-year-old boy with repaired/palliated congenital heart disease is seen for elective circumcision requested for religious reasons. He is thriving, but cardiology notes his anesthetic risk is higher than peers. Pediatric anesthesia has evaluated him and will proceed with added cardiac precautions for a brief case, though they cannot make the risk zero. There is no medical indication for circumcision. The child cannot understand the procedure and strongly resists genital exams. Office-based circumcision with local anesthesia is not feasible at his age and behavior, and would still require deep sedation. His parents want the circumcision completed before a fixed community ceremony next month. Referral to a tertiary cardiac center or an ethics consult cannot be arranged before the scheduling deadline. The parents say that if this hospital will not schedule it, they will seek circumcision in another setting with less reliable sterility, analgesia, and ability to manage bleeding. Hospital policy and state law permit either performing elective circumcision with anesthesia approval or declining nonindicated surgery.

choice_1.choice: Schedule elective circumcision this month with pediatric cardiac anesthesia and OR support.

choice_2.choice: Decline to perform circumcision; counsel, document, and arrange follow-up planning.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the parents have been fully informed of the increased anesthetic/cardiac risks and still insist, and explicitly note the team’s concern about proceeding despite the child’s active resistance (dissent) and inability to consent.

Add one clause specifying what concrete benefit to the child is expected from doing it now (e.g., avoids a highly likely circumcision in a less safe setting / prevents serious social consequences if missed), and one clause estimating the anesthesia/cardiac complication risk so the benefit–risk tradeoff for the child is explicit.

Add a clause that OR/pediatric cardiac anesthesia time is scarce (e.g., urgent cardiac cases are being delayed or there is a long surgical waitlist), so scheduling a nonindicated high-resource case would displace other children.

data.vignette: A 3-year-old boy with repaired/palliated congenital heart disease is seen for elective circumcision requested for religious reasons. He is thriving, but cardiology notes his anesthetic risk is higher than peers, including possible cardiopulmonary instability that could require escalation of care. Pediatric anesthesia has evaluated him and will proceed with added cardiac precautions for a brief case, though they cannot make the risk zero. There is no medical indication for circumcision. The child cannot understand the procedure and strongly resists genital exams, which raises concern about proceeding despite his active dissent. Office-based circumcision with local anesthesia is not feasible at his age and behavior and would still require deep sedation. His parents have been informed of the increased cardiac and anesthesia risks and still insist that it be completed before a fixed community ceremony next month. Referral to a tertiary cardiac center or an ethics consult cannot be arranged before the scheduling deadline. The parents say that if this hospital will not schedule it, they will seek circumcision in another setting with less reliable sterility, analgesia, and ability to manage bleeding. OR time and pediatric cardiac anesthesia coverage are limited, and adding this elective case may delay other children’s time-sensitive surgeries. Hospital policy and state law permit either performing elective circumcision with anesthesia approval or declining nonindicated surgery.

choice_1.choice: Schedule elective circumcision this month with pediatric cardiac anesthesia and OR support.

choice_2.choice: Decline to perform circumcision; counsel, document, and arrange follow-up planning.
